doc.field: The autograph book of Brooklyn resident Edith M. Crouse, with entries dated 1887-1893, many of which seem to relate to Crouse's 1888 graduation from P.S. 9.
The autograph book of Brooklyn resident Edith M. Crouse, with entries dated 1887-1893, many of which seem to relate to Crouse's 1888 graduation from P.S. 9.

The autograph book of Brooklyn resident Edith M. Crouse. The entries in the book appear to have been written by friends and classmates, and many are signed "Class of 1888." According to the Brooklyn Times Union, Crouse was among the graduates of "School No. 9," later P.S. 9.
Edith M. Crouse lived at 214 Lincoln Place in Brooklyn. She graduated from Brooklyn's School No. 9 in 1888.

Brooklyn's School No. 9 was built 1867â€“68 and designed by Samuel B. Leonard in the Early Romanesque Revival style. Its two wings were added in 1887 and were designed by James W. Naughton. The school was originally Public School (P.S.) 9, later becoming Public School 111, and is currently M.S. 340, North Star Academy. The building was designated a New York City landmark in 1978 and listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1981.
Source and date of acquisition unknown. The item was formally accessioned in 1978.
